newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian sugar advances on low stocks, arrivals.
newsitem.headline: Indian sugar advances on low stocks, arrivals.

text.p: Sugar prices rose in India on Wednesday as shortages of ready stock encouraged speculators in a market, but consumer demand dried up at the higher levels, traders said.
In the ready delivery sugar S-30 climbed up by 10/15 rupees at 1,390/1,440 rupees per quintal while sugar M-30 settled five rupees higher at 1,440/1,505 rupees per quintal.

"Arrivals remained low and pipelines are more or less empty due to lower trading last week between millers and traders on fear that government may release more free sale quota," said Praful Shah, a leading broker.
"Empty pipelines have created shortage of ready stock which led to quick buoyancy in the prices," he said.
Meanwhile sugar mill delivery moved up by five rupees at 1,340/1,360 rupees per quintal.
"Outstation buying remained higher at the mill level which has also curtailed arrivals of sugar from mills to the Bombay market," Shah said.
Bombay sugar market will remain closed on Thursday for birth anniversary of king Shivaji. The market will reopen for trading on Friday. --Bombay Commodities +91-22-265 9000
